In a more formal register, this nominalizer is pronounced (n)khen,[1] whereas in conversation it is usually pronounced as ངན་, and even ཉན་. The verb to which it is attached takes the present-future.

  • ཞུ་མཁན་ But not *ཞུས་མཁན་
  • ཟ་མཁན་ But not *བཟས་མཁན་
  • ལྟ་མཁན་ But not *བལྟས་མཁན་

Like other nominalizers, མཁན་ can form nominal clauses as well as relative clauses. This nominalizer prototypically indicates the agent of the verbal action, but also extends to the subject of transitive verbs and even (in most cases) to the subject of intransitive verbs.

  • འབྲི་མཁན་ “The person who writes,” “the writer”
  • ཞུ་མཁན་ “The person who is speaking,” “the speaker”
  • ཟ་མཁན་ “The person who is eating”
  • ཚོང་མཁན་ “The person who is selling,” “the vendor”
  • རྨི་ལམ་བཏང་མཁན་ “The dreamer”
  • ཉལ་མཁན་ “The person who is sleeping,” “the sleeper”

Formulations with མཁན་ may sometimes be translated by terms for agents in European languages. In English, the suffix –er or the name of a profession often best conveys the sense of this nominalizer.

  • ཁོང་བག་ལེབ་བཟོ་མཁན་རེད། “He’s a baker.” (Literally: “He’s a bread-maker”)
  • ང་རང་ཚོའི་གྲོགས་པོ་རྒྱ་མི་དེ་གློག་བརྙན་བཟོ་མཁན་རེད། “Our Chinese friend is a film-maker.”
  • ཐ་མག་འཐེན་མཁན་འདི་སུ་རེད། “Who’s the person who’s smoking?” Or, “Who’s the smoker?”
  • མོ་ཊ་ནག་པོ་ཡོད་མཁན་དེ་རྫོང་དཔོན་གཅིག་རེད། “The person who has the black car is the mayor of a district.” Or, “The owner of the black car is....”

In certain cases, verbs that are nominalized with མཁན་ are practically the same as conjugated verbs. For example, the sentence: ང་ཡའི་(ཡང་)འགྲོ་མཁན་ཡིན། “I’m also going,” which literally means: “I’m also a goer” is similar to: ང་ཡའི་(ཡང་)འགྲོ་གི་ཡིན།.

[1] The nasal (n) that is noted here is a velar nasal (a nasal homorganic with the follow­ing consonant). This nasal, which is preserved in Tibetan spelling, is the source of two current pronunciations: ངན་ (a velar nasal) and ཉན་ (a palatal nasal). As far as the written form is concerned, in my discussions I retain the traditional spelling མཁན་, since ངན་ and ཉན་ never appear in writing.
